item.title: Questions for two Commission Vice-Presidents on EU foreign policy, human rights, and institutional reform.
item.description:
By Emilio DE CAPITANI, Henri LABAYLE and Steve PEERS This week, Members of the European Parliament (MEPs) will continue interviewing candidates for the next European Commission to decide on its confirmation. MEPs have already posed written questions and received responses. However, the upcoming oral hearings offer MEPs a crucial opportunity to understand the Commissioners’ intentions and secure key political promises. This blog post proposes questions for MEPs to ask two potential Commission Vice-Presidents: the High Representative for the Common Foreign and Security Policy and Commission Vice President for external relations (Mogherini), and the Commissioner for Better Regulation, Fundamental Rights and the Rule of Law (Timmermans)...

item.title: Access to documents: The Council may choose not to enforce a significant CJEU ruling.
item.description:
Steve Peers The EU is frequently criticized for its lack of transparency, particularly concerning its legislative processes. Ideally, these processes should be as open as those in national legislatures, allowing public access to draft legislation. However, despite a 2001 regulation on public access to documents, EU transparency in this area remains an issue. Within the Council, some Member States prefer to keep their positions confidential during negotiations. This secrecy undermines the idea that citizens, through their national parliaments, can hold their governments accountable for actions taken within the Council...

item.title: Labuan IBFC places a strong emphasis on ensuring compliance and transparency in all business activities
item.description:
Following the release of the Panama Papers, the Labuan International Business and Financial Centre (Labuan IBFC) has reaffirmed its commitment to facilitating cross-border trade and investment, especially within the ASEAN region. The organization emphasizes its dedication to maintaining strict transparency and regulatory standards for all business activities conducted within the centre. In a statement, the organization highlighted its continuous efforts to strengthen its regulatory framework and supervisory system. item.title: Is privacy prioritized over transparency in CJEU cases?
item.description:
Peter Oliver, Barrister, Monckton Chambers; Visiting Professor, Université Libre de Bruxelles Having a name is essential, as not having one can lead to problems. This is why courts in Strasbourg and Luxembourg have acknowledged a person’s fundamental right to use their own name. The Court of Justice has traditionally used initials to protect the identities of vulnerable individuals like asylum seekers and children involved in sensitive litigation. However, in a recent announcement, the Court stated its intention to partially overturn this long-standing practice...

item.title: A leaked document discloses that the EU is considering suspending the Schengen agreement for a period of two years.
item.description:
Commentary by Steve Peers This is Council document 14300/15, from December 1, 2015, called “Integrity of the Schengen area,” and sent to Coreper (representatives of EU member states) and the Council - likely the Justice and Home Affairs ministers meeting December 3rd and 4th. (An official version of the document is available here). The first three sections are relatively standard (see here for discussion), but section 4 proposes initiating a process to formally permit the reinstatement of internal border controls within the Schengen zone for a duration of up to two years...
